subject: RE: {External} RE: Confirming ARCH Canada First Cohort dates/times
body:
Hi Rebecca,
 
Thanks for following up. We just met with our Canada team this morning, which is what I was waiting on before responding. They actually discussed having the Leading Inclusively session earlier. They requested 11am-2pm ET. Can you check if this timing would work for the facilitator? We are getting much closer to launching this in Canada.
 
Thanks,
Evan

Subject:
 ARCH Canada New Cohort Options
 
Hey Rebecca and Juri,
 
I hope all is well. We were just discussing the possibility of switching Canada’s program to package their program as a cohort. This would entail keeping the May sessions but having the first date be for UYCL and the second date being for the Leading Inclusively session rather that another UYCL. We would then do the same thing in October/November. Would this option work with your team and facilitators? I want to check before pitching this idea to our Canada team. 
 
Let me know and thank you,
 
Evan

subject: RE: LCW x GroupM Meeting + Scheduling Sessions
body:
Hi Rebecca: 
 
Some responses and additional thoughts: 
 
I don’t have the talk track on the Barriers to Inclusion slide, but I agree with Lukeisha that I’m not entirely sure it fits. What would it look like without identifiers? Can you share that please? 
Yes—I’m good with the changes on the Platinum rule slide
I also flagged for Lukeisha that Denial and Polarization examples. I really like the global example that you shared for Polarization and I think that’s the winner. If you don’t want it, I also think the Polarization can get the same treatment as denial “Why do we have to make a big deal out of cultural differences?” I also think there is something off about the example of Adaptation. I’m not sure what the examples have to do with working with the ERGs or increasing retention. Can this be made any clearer? 
For other slides—On slide 2 and 3 we say “GroupM DEI Leads with Inclusion.” Can this be changed to just “GroupM Leads with Inclusion” ? 
Regarding the introductory activity on slide 5, we’re wondering if we need to change the speaker notes to remove the explicit instructions to avoid superficial ways of introducing themselves. If we stick with the example in the introduction (“
I’m a returned ex-pat who lived and worked in Shanghai, China for a couple of years.”) that might still accomplish the same tone without making some people uncomfortable about participating. 
 
Do these changes make sense ?
 
Best,
Brian
 
 
BRIAN DASHEW 
(he/him)
Head of Learning, North America
— 
www.groupm.com
 
@groupmworldwide
 
Follow us on LinkedIn

 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:

External:
 
 
Thank you. I found the details in 
this article
 which summarizes things, and 
here
 is the actual EEOC language. 
 
This part of the summary article is interesting:
With respect to training, the EEOC states that:
“DEI training 
may 
give rise to a 
colorable
 hostile work environment claim”; and
“Reasonable opposition to a DEI training 
may
 constitute protected activity.”
 
I looked it up and a "colorable hostile work environment claim" refers to a situation where an employee alleges that their workplace has become abusive or intimidating due to unwelcome conduct based on their protected characteristic (like race, color, religion, sex, etc.) and that this conduct is severe or pervasive enough to create a hostile environment, potentially giving rise to a valid legal claim. There is NOTHING that I see in the content as-is that would reasonably be constituted as “abusive or intimidating”.
 
 
My POV regarding the three slides you sent through:
 
Slide 1 – I would recommend keeping this slide and removing the diversity identifiers on each quote. We want to make sure that we educate around the presence of all five of these barriers, which are not solely and exclusively experienced by POC, women, LGBTQ+, PwD or other non-dominant groups. They are experienced by people of ALL backgrounds. We know that often they are experienced more often by people of non-dominant groups, but everyone can think of examples where they were afraid of being stereotyped, where they covered, where they experienced greater scrutiny, etc. 
 
Slide 2- No, the religious reference is not necessary, I will delete it. I will change the image – is this image okay?
 
Slide 3 – 
for Denial, I will change the quote to “I’m not sure why we 
need to learn about people’s different cultures
. If people really want to work here, then they’ll stay here. If they leave then they probably weren’t a good fit anyway.”  
May I ask for the reasoning behind having a different example of Polarization is required? Currently it’s “Why do we have to say our pronouns? All for a few people who insist on complicating things - why should they receive special treatment?” At any rate, a different example could be: “I just don’t understand why some global teams don’t ask questions during project meetings, it’s so counterproductive and irritating!”
Re: Debrief poll for acceptance / adaptation coming across as leading and judgmental, we do objectively know that most people who self assess in the intercultural mindsets are in fact in Minimization, but we don’t have to say that. I will change the speaker notes to simply reiterate what acceptance and adaptation mean, and encourage people to continue practicing understanding and bridging. 
 
Best, 
Rebecca
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

subject: RE: LCW x GroupM Meeting + Scheduling Sessions
body:
Thank you. I found the details in 
this article
 which summarizes things, and 
here
 is the actual EEOC language. 
 
This part of the summary article is interesting:
With respect to training, the EEOC states that:
“DEI training 
may 
give rise to a 
colorable
 hostile work environment claim”; and
“Reasonable opposition to a DEI training 
may
 constitute protected activity.”
 
I looked it up and a "colorable hostile work environment claim" refers to a situation where an employee alleges that their workplace has become abusive or intimidating due to unwelcome conduct based on their protected characteristic (like race, color, religion, sex, etc.) and that this conduct is severe or pervasive enough to create a hostile environment, potentially giving rise to a valid legal claim. There is NOTHING that I see in the content as-is that would reasonably be constituted as “abusive or intimidating”.
 
 
My POV regarding the three slides you sent through:
 
Slide 1 – I would recommend keeping this slide and removing the diversity identifiers on each quote. We want to make sure that we educate around the presence of all five of these barriers, which are not solely and exclusively experienced by POC, women, LGBTQ+, PwD or other non-dominant groups. They are experienced by people of ALL backgrounds. We know that often they are experienced more often by people of non-dominant groups, but everyone can think of examples where they were afraid of being stereotyped, where they covered, where they experienced greater scrutiny, etc. 
 
Slide 2- No, the religious reference is not necessary, I will delete it. I will change the image – is this image okay?
 
Slide 3 – 
for Denial, I will change the quote to “I’m not sure why we 
need to learn about people’s different cultures
. If people really want to work here, then they’ll stay here. If they leave then they probably weren’t a good fit anyway.”  
May I ask for the reasoning behind having a different example of Polarization is required? Currently it’s “Why do we have to say our pronouns? All for a few people who insist on complicating things - why should they receive special treatment?” At any rate, a different example could be: “I just don’t understand why some global teams don’t ask questions during project meetings, it’s so counterproductive and irritating!”
Re: Debrief poll for acceptance / adaptation coming across as leading and judgmental, we do objectively know that most people who self assess in the intercultural mindsets are in fact in Minimization, but we don’t have to say that. I will change the speaker notes to simply reiterate what acceptance and adaptation mean, and encourage people to continue practicing understanding and bridging. 
 
Best, 
Rebecca
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW

Subject:
 Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
 
Hi Lukeisha: 
 
I met this morning with Shelton and the LCW team to go over the possibility of automatic calendar notifications through the Zoom enrollment process. While the Zoom link does prompt users to add the item to their calendar (which happens automatically once the user selects to add the event), there is unfortunately no easy way for their registration to automatically trigger the calendar event creation. 
 
That effectively leaves us with two options: 
Use Zoom registrations which will address the issue of logins and email fidelity, but which requires the user to select the option to have the calendar event created
Use EventBrite which will address the issue of calendar notifications, but which will leave the problem of logins in place. 
 
My recommendation is that the Zoom registration option has enough practical benefits that it outweighs the potential risk of users needing to select for the calendar invitation. This is especially true because it would still send automatic notifications of enrollment and reminder messages. I do caveat this recommendation with two things: 
 
I think we should revisit after the first round of enrollments. If we find that we have seen a precipitous drop in attendance from enrollment (e.g. 80%) then I think we should revert to the EventBrite approach. 
We have asked for LCW to also confirm that a) we can limit the number of sessions an individual can enroll for, and b) they can cancel registrations if they are unable to attend
 
Wanted to check with you before we move this ahead. Are you comfortable with this approach? 
 
Best,
Brian
 
BRIAN DASHEW 
(he/him)
Head of Learning, North America
— 
www.groupm.com
 
@groupmworldwide
 
Follow us on LinkedIn

Hi, team. One thing I was looking forward to pinning down today was the 
start of session deployment
. 
 
I’m so sorry but it’s become very hard for us as a small firm to continue reserving resources (facilitators) on particular dates/times only to postpone since mid-February, and at this point it’s a high priority item for LCW and our CEO to get the sessions hard-scheduled asap.  
Can we say with certainty that the first sessions will take place on Friday, May 2
nd
?
 
 
I thought it would be helpful to also review the cancellations and postponement language in the SOW – I will waive the fees that would have been incurred re: the last bullet up until now:
 
Cancelations
 
&
 
Postponements:
Scheduled sessions may be canceled or postponed at any time before scheduled delivery at no cost, providing the session is rescheduled within six months, any non-refundable travel expenses will still be billed
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 8-14 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 3-7 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 75% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 2 days of delivery, if not rescheduled will incur a charge of the full program fee, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Cancellation and postponement charges will be invoiced immediately and may not be applied to future sessions Cancellation & postponement fees are in addition to the original session fees
Scheduled sessions postponed more than twice, no matter the notice, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
 
If we believe a meeting is necessary to talk about the above, I’d prefer the meeting be held sooner rather than later.
 
Thanks, and I look forward to your response!
Best, 
Rebecca

To:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>; Juri Mansour <j.mansour@lcwmail.com>; Safa Aamir <safa.aamir@groupm.com>; Brian Dashew <brian.dashew@groupm.com>; Shelton Rankin <shelton.rankin@groupm.com>
Subject:
 RE: LCW x GroupM Meeting + Scheduling Sessions
 
Hi Rebecca,
 
We understand the need from a business perspective to get this finalized asap and appreciate LCW’s patience and understanding as we work through the best way and time to deliver this important content to our employees.  
 
Early last week I mentioned we were in a great place to kick off and was just waiting to see if the Zoom tests worked which they did.  However, solidified guidelines from the DOJ and EEOC came out last week that made us want to reevaluate our program to ensure we are in guidance with the law.  As such, I have now reviewed the content (attached for your review and POV).  There are a few things I believe we need to consider from the slides to the accompanying notes.  
@Brian Dashew
 can you review my suggestions and add any thoughts you may have as well.  Once we align on these changes we can move forward on sending out our comms to get started on our sessions. 
 
If there are an questions please let me know.  We can reschedule our meeting for this week to agree on next steps and timeline. 
 
Thank you everyone,

>
Subject:
 LCW x GroupM Meeting + Scheduling Sessions
 
External:
 
 
Hi, team. One thing I was looking forward to pinning down today was the 
start of session deployment
. 
 
I’m so sorry but it’s become very hard for us as a small firm to continue reserving resources (facilitators) on particular dates/times only to postpone since mid-February, and at this point it’s a high priority item for LCW and our CEO to get the sessions hard-scheduled asap.  
Can we say with certainty that the first sessions will take place on Friday, May 2
nd
?
 
 
I thought it would be helpful to also review the cancellations and postponement language in the SOW – I will waive the fees that would have been incurred re: the last bullet up until now:
 
Cancelations
 
&
 
Postponements:
Scheduled sessions may be canceled or postponed at any time before scheduled delivery at no cost, providing the session is rescheduled within six months, any non-refundable travel expenses will still be billed
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 8-14 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 3-7 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 75% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 2 days of delivery, if not rescheduled will incur a charge of the full program fee, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Cancellation and postponement charges will be invoiced immediately and may not be applied to future sessions Cancellation & postponement fees are in addition to the original session fees
Scheduled sessions postponed more than twice, no matter the notice, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
 
If we believe a meeting is necessary to talk about the above, I’d prefer the meeting be held sooner rather than later.
 
Thanks, and I look forward to your response!
Best, 
Rebecca
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW

External:
 
 
Hi team,
 
I just wanted to add some information here regarding the Zoom registration:
 
Zoom has the option where the registrants need to register separately for each occurrence to attend. They can only choose one date and time on the registrant page. If the registrant cancels, they will need to re-register to attend any future sessions. 
 
  2. Registrant cancellations:  Zoom does NOT send an email to the host when a registrant cancels their     registration. The host has to manually check the registrant list within the Zoom web portal to see who     has cancelled. 
 
    We can pull registration reports- would you want to pull this information in the same cadence of        sending the reminders? Shelton shared that the session reminders cadence would be 5  days prior       to a session, 3 days prior to a session, and 1 day prior to a session.  Please confirm.
 
Thanks!
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW
From:
 Brian Dashew <
brian.dashew@groupm.com
>
Sent:
 Wednesday, March 26, 2025 8:43 AM
To:
 Lukeisha Paul <
Lukeisha.Paul@groupm.com
>; Shelton Rankin <
shelton.rankin@groupm.com
>; Juri Mansour <
j.mansour@lcwmail.com
>; Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
 
Hi Lukeisha: 
 
I met this morning with Shelton and the LCW team to go over the possibility of automatic calendar notifications through the Zoom enrollment process. While the Zoom link does prompt users to add the item to their calendar (which happens automatically once the user selects to add the event), there is unfortunately no easy way for their registration to automatically trigger the calendar event creation. 
 
That effectively leaves us with two options: 
Use Zoom registrations which will address the issue of logins and email fidelity, but which requires the user to select the option to have the calendar event created
Use EventBrite which will address the issue of calendar notifications, but which will leave the problem of logins in place. 
 
My recommendation is that the Zoom registration option has enough practical benefits that it outweighs the potential risk of users needing to select for the calendar invitation. This is especially true because it would still send automatic notifications of enrollment and reminder messages. I do caveat this recommendation with two things: 
 
I think we should revisit after the first round of enrollments. If we find that we have seen a precipitous drop in attendance from enrollment (e.g. 80%) then I think we should revert to the EventBrite approach. 
We have asked for LCW to also confirm that a) we can limit the number of sessions an individual can enroll for, and b) they can cancel registrations if they are unable to attend
 
Wanted to check with you before we move this ahead. Are you comfortable with this approach? 
 
Best,
Brian
 
BRIAN DASHEW 
(he/him)
Head of Learning, North America
— 
www.groupm.com
 
@groupmworldwide
 
Follow us on LinkedIn

subject: LCW x GroupM Meeting + Scheduling Sessions
body:
Hi, team. One thing I was looking forward to pinning down today was the 
start of session deployment
. 
 
I’m so sorry but it’s become very hard for us as a small firm to continue reserving resources (facilitators) on particular dates/times only to postpone since mid-February, and at this point it’s a high priority item for LCW and our CEO to get the sessions hard-scheduled asap.  
Can we say with certainty that the first sessions will take place on Friday, May 2
nd
?
 
 
I thought it would be helpful to also review the cancellations and postponement language in the SOW – I will waive the fees that would have been incurred re: the last bullet up until now:
 
Cancelations
 
&
 
Postponements:
Scheduled sessions may be canceled or postponed at any time before scheduled delivery at no cost, providing the session is rescheduled within six months, any non-refundable travel expenses will still be billed
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 8-14 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 3-7 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 75% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 2 days of delivery, if not rescheduled will incur a charge of the full program fee, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
Cancellation and postponement charges will be invoiced immediately and may not be applied to future sessions Cancellation & postponement fees are in addition to the original session fees
Scheduled sessions postponed more than twice, no matter the notice, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses
 
If we believe a meeting is necessary to talk about the above, I’d prefer the meeting be held sooner rather than later.
 
Thanks, and I look forward to your response!
Best, 
Rebecca
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW

r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
External:
 
 
Hi team,
 
I just wanted to add some information here regarding the Zoom registration:
 
Zoom has the option where the registrants need to register separately for each occurrence to attend. They can only choose one date and time on the registrant page. If the registrant cancels, they will need to re-register to attend any future sessions. 
 
  2. Registrant cancellations:  Zoom does NOT send an email to the host when a registrant cancels their     registration. The host has to manually check the registrant list within the Zoom web portal to see who     has cancelled. 
 
    We can pull registration reports- would you want to pull this information in the same cadence of        sending the reminders? Shelton shared that the session reminders cadence would be 5  days prior       to a session, 3 days prior to a session, and 1 day prior to a session.  Please confirm.
 
Thanks!
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW
From:
 Brian Dashew <
brian.dashew@groupm.com
>
Sent:
 Wednesday, March 26, 2025 8:43 AM
To:
 Lukeisha Paul <
Lukeisha.Paul@groupm.com
>; Shelton Rankin <
shelton.rankin@groupm.com
>; Juri Mansour <
j.mansour@lcwmail.com
>; Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
 
Hi Lukeisha: 
 
I met this morning with Shelton and the LCW team to go over the possibility of automatic calendar notifications through the Zoom enrollment process. While the Zoom link does prompt users to add the item to their calendar (which happens automatically once the user selects to add the event), there is unfortunately no easy way for their registration to automatically trigger the calendar event creation. 
 
That effectively leaves us with two options: 
Use Zoom registrations which will address the issue of logins and email fidelity, but which requires the user to select the option to have the calendar event created
Use EventBrite which will address the issue of calendar notifications, but which will leave the problem of logins in place. 
 
My recommendation is that the Zoom registration option has enough practical benefits that it outweighs the potential risk of users needing to select for the calendar invitation. This is especially true because it would still send automatic notifications of enrollment and reminder messages. I do caveat this recommendation with two things: 
 
I think we should revisit after the first round of enrollments. If we find that we have seen a precipitous drop in attendance from enrollment (e.g. 80%) then I think we should revert to the EventBrite approach. 
We have asked for LCW to also confirm that a) we can limit the number of sessions an individual can enroll for, and b) they can cancel registrations if they are unable to attend
 
Wanted to check with you before we move this ahead. Are you comfortable with this approach? 
 
Best,
Brian
 
BRIAN DASHEW 
(he/him)
Head of Learning, North America
— 
www.groupm.com
 
@groupmworldwide
 
Follow us on LinkedIn

Subject:
 Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
Hi Lukeisha: 
 
I met this morning with Shelton and the LCW team to go over the possibility of automatic calendar notifications through the Zoom enrollment process. While the Zoom link does prompt users to add the item to their calendar (which happens automatically once the user selects to add the event), there is unfortunately no easy way for their registration to automatically trigger the calendar event creation. 
 
That effectively leaves us with two options: 
Use Zoom registrations which will address the issue of logins and email fidelity, but which requires the user to select the option to have the calendar event created
Use EventBrite which will address the issue of calendar notifications, but which will leave the problem of logins in place. 
 
My recommendation is that the Zoom registration option has enough practical benefits that it outweighs the potential risk of users needing to select for the calendar invitation. This is especially true because it would still send automatic notifications of enrollment and reminder messages. I do caveat this recommendation with two things: 
 
I think we should revisit after the first round of enrollments. If we find that we have seen a precipitous drop in attendance from enrollment (e.g. 80%) then I think we should revert to the EventBrite approach. 
We have asked for LCW to also confirm that a) we can limit the number of sessions an individual can enroll for, and b) they can cancel registrations if they are unable to attend
 
Wanted to check with you before we move this ahead. Are you comfortable with this approach? 
 
Best,
Brian
 
BRIAN DASHEW 
(he/him)
Head of Learning, North America
— 
www.groupm.com
 
@groupmworldwide
 
Follow us on LinkedIn

 Brian Dashew <brian.dashew@groupm.com>; Lukeisha Paul <Lukeisha.Paul@groupm.com>; Shelton Rankin <shelton.rankin@groupm.com>; Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
External:
 
 
Hi team,
 
I just wanted to add some information here regarding the Zoom registration:
 
Zoom has the option where the registrants need to register separately for each occurrence to attend. They can only choose one date and time on the registrant page. If the registrant cancels, they will need to re-register to attend any future sessions. 
 
  2. Registrant cancellations:  Zoom does NOT send an email to the host when a registrant cancels their     registration. The host has to manually check the registrant list within the Zoom web portal to see who     has cancelled. 
 
    We can pull registration reports- would you want to pull this information in the same cadence of        sending the reminders? Shelton shared that the session reminders cadence would be 5  days prior       to a session, 3 days prior to a session, and 1 day prior to a session.  Please confirm.
 
Thanks!
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

j.mansour@lcwmail.com
>; Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
 
 
Hi Lukeisha: 
 
I met this morning with Shelton and the LCW team to go over the possibility of automatic calendar notifications through the Zoom enrollment process. While the Zoom link does prompt users to add the item to their calendar (which happens automatically once the user selects to add the event), there is unfortunately no easy way for their registration to automatically trigger the calendar event creation. 
 
That effectively leaves us with two options: 
Use Zoom registrations which will address the issue of logins and email fidelity, but which requires the user to select the option to have the calendar event created
Use EventBrite which will address the issue of calendar notifications, but which will leave the problem of logins in place. 
 
My recommendation is that the Zoom registration option has enough practical benefits that it outweighs the potential risk of users needing to select for the calendar invitation. This is especially true because it would still send automatic notifications of enrollment and reminder messages. I do caveat this recommendation with two things: 
 
I think we should revisit after the first round of enrollments. If we find that we have seen a precipitous drop in attendance from enrollment (e.g. 80%) then I think we should revert to the EventBrite approach. 
We have asked for LCW to also confirm that a) we can limit the number of sessions an individual can enroll for, and b) they can cancel registrations if they are unable to attend
 
Wanted to check with you before we move this ahead. Are you comfortable with this approach? 
 
Best,
Brian
 
BRIAN DASHEW 
(he/him)
Head of Learning, North America
— 
www.groupm.com
 
@groupmworldwide
 
Follow us on LinkedIn

subject: Re: Recommendation on Culture of Inclusion program enrollment
body:
Hi team,
I just wanted to add some information here regarding the Zoom registration:
Zoom has the option where the registrants need to register separately for each occurrence to attend. They can only choose one date and time on the registrant page. If the registrant cancels, they will need to re-register to attend any future sessions. 
  2. Registrant cancellations:  Zoom does NOT send an email to the host when a registrant cancels their     registration. The host has to manually check the registrant list within the Zoom web portal to see who     has cancelled. 
    We can pull registration reports- would you want to pull this information in the same cadence of        sending the reminders? Shelton shared that the session reminders cadence would be 5  days prior       to a session, 3 days prior to a session, and 1 day prior to a session.  Please confirm.
Thanks!
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

I hope all is well. We were just discussing the possibility of switching Canada’s program to package their program as a cohort. Subject:
 RE: {External} Schedule 15-min call to meet facilitator?
 
Removed Joyce and Samrat from the CC list.
--
Happy Friday, team, 
 
Please find the finalized participant list attached. A few key points to note:
 
Penang site arrangements: Due to Penang site regulations on food entry, all Penang-based participants will attend both sessions together in one meeting room, as mentioned earlier. Please help arrange the breakout setup so they can join the offline breakout group discussions.
HRLT participation highlight:
Daphne Ong, VP HR, APAC, will join both sessions. She’s been a strong supporter of bringing ARCH to APAC from the start, and her presence will be invaluable. Unfortunately, she has a prior commitment as a speaker at an ESG event and will need to step away during the second hour of session 1. It’s not ideal, and I appreciate your support in helping her catch up for session 2.
Priscilla Hua, HR Leader, Greater China, will attend session 1 only. Unfortunately, she has a key role in the PI kick-off meeting in China next week. She adjusted her flight to join session 1 but can’t extend her schedule for session 2. Given her leadership and commitment, we agreed to make an exception for her to attend session 1 only this round. I appreciate your kind understanding.
 
I’ve also attached the updated BSC Employee Engagement Pulse Survey results, including Penang data.
 
On a separate note, I’m looking forward to meeting with Yuko next Monday. Please let me know if there’s anything else needed from my side. Thank you. 
 
Have a great weekend ahead,
Rose

Subject:
 RE: {External} Schedule 15-min call to meet facilitator?
 
Hi Rebecca,
 
Lovely to hear from you! It would be great to meet Yuko. I’m available at 8-9 AM SGT next Monday and Tuesday — please let me know which slot works best for her.
 
I’ll follow Joyce’s advice on the lunch break. We learnt that our Penang manufacturing site has specific regulations on food entry into the workplace. The team will need to book a meeting room so that they can attend the training and have a working lunch, as eating at their cubicles isn’t allowed.
 
Evan and I connected yesterday on other preparations. Our class registration reached 49 pax — just one more to go. I’ll make a final push to those yet to register and share the participant list with this group by Friday US time, so you can use it to plan the virtual breakouts.
 
Additionally, I’ll be sending over the APAC Employee Engagement index (including Penang) that we agreed to incorporate into the LI session.
 
@Tarshish, Evan (he/him/his)
 — feel free to add anything I may have missed.
 
Looking forward to the session!
 
Best regards,
Rose

subject: ARCH Canada New Cohort Options
body:
Hey Rebecca and Juri,
 
I hope all is well. We were just discussing the possibility of switching Canada’s program to package their program as a cohort. This would entail keeping the May sessions but having the first date be for UYCL and the second date being for the Leading Inclusively session rather that another UYCL. We would then do the same thing in October/November. Would this option work with your team and facilitators? I want to check before pitching this idea to our Canada team. 
 
Let me know and thank you,
 
Evan
 
 
 
Evan Tarshish
DE&I Talent Management Principal Specialist
Enterprise Talent Management  
www.bostonscientific.com

I’ll follow Joyce’s advice on the lunch break. We learnt that our Penang manufacturing site has specific regulations on food entry into the workplace. Some LMS and company security environments can have an impact on the size of certain projects loaded onto an LMS. That doesn't mean anything is wrong with the size of the current package, but something I made their team aware of early on. I've seen some LMS that have a limit on the size of courses. Should they need an adjustment in the course size for them, the videos would need to be re-encoded for a smaller file size. Let's see if they have an issue before quoting a few more hours to re-encode and craft a new wrapper.
 
If they tested MBR and it works, that was the largest file, so perhaps we're all good?
 
Best,
Dustin
 
On Wed, Dec 11, 2024 at 4:27
 
PM Patricia Coleman <
p.coleman@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Hi Dustin,
 
We had our last scheduled call of the year with ColPal.
 
First, of all, they are wondering if it is possible to add a survey link ( they would provide) to the package so that participants give their feedback after each e-learning. Let me know if that is doable and if so, out of the type of files, multi vs single scorm, which one can update the current uploaded files without replacing them ( if that is at all possible). Then, we can talk time needed and your fee separately. 
  
ML Recruiting uploaded, tested and works. CBS is working fast, that’s good!
 
Possible COLPAL MLS reported issue ( not LCW):
It seems that 1 or maybe 2 ML(s) are too big to upload. Al is checking precedents of this issue as they may have a solution.
 
Al shared that they have had bigger files in the past with up to 12  languages. He will advise and ONLY loop back to us if they cannot identify the issue.
 
Dustin, Chuck: Have you encountered this issue before?
 
 
Let me know if you have any questions,
 
Patricia

subject: FYI re: BSC LATAM translation question BSC brought up today
body:
Hi, pls see below. 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW
 
 
From:
 Rebecca Parrilla 
Sent:
 Wednesday, March 19, 2025 4:38 PM
To:
 Cecilia Mariotta <c.mariotta@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>; Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 how much do we pay reviewers?
 
Hi Cecilia, how are you?  I’m talking with Boston scientific, one of our biggest clients, about allowing them to use internal translators to translate two different PPT presentations into Spanish and Portuguese. I’m speaking with Chuck and Nicole about allowing that, as long as we are able to QA the translation and approve them, keeping the integrity of the content and our intellectual property. 
 
How much would we typically charge a client to QA the Spanish (LatAm) and Portuguese (Brazil) translations for: 
This PPT
 (video on slide 3 which has script in the speaker notes) and
This PPT
: 
Slide 19: Video: 
¿México e racista o colorista?” 
 (which came from 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5fgOrV2uJUU
) 
– video is on Spanish, so only needed to translate into PTB
Slide 22: Video: 
 “Indigenas Urbanos: Los desafios de los pueblos indigenas en ciudades
” (which came from 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bl9viILCREM
) 
– 
video is on Spanish, so only needed to translate into PTB
Slide 30: Video: “A Class Divided” (see attached for script). 
This video is located 
here
 (in our Dropbox) but we only need until 8:42 (“…it’s a horrid day”). Even when I download the video from the workshop deck (which is 8:42) it provides me with the longer 13:25 version!
There is also a Quiz on Zoom which would also need translation (see attached for English).
 
We’d be QAing 
the slides only (not the speaker notes
, they will not translate those) and the 
videos would need subtitles only
. 
 
And how much do we typically pay reviewers to do this?
 
Gracias!
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
We help develop the mindsets and systems needed to foster resilient, diverse, and equitable teams that will be successful in a cross-cultural world.

|

|
 
LinkedIn
 
I live and work in Chapel Hill, NC – on the traditional homelands of the Occaneechi, Shakori, Eno, and Sissipahaw peoples.

 Thursday, March 6, 2025 9:20 AM
To:
 Patricia Coleman <p.coleman@lcwmail.com>; Elixir Multimedia Solutions <elixirmultimediasolutions@gmail.com>; Dustin Puehler <d.puehler@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Claudia Solorzano <claudia_solorzano@colpal.com>; Jesma Johnson <jesma_johnson@colpal.com>
Subject:
 Microlearning SCORM issue
 
 
Hello Patricia & Dustin, 
I hope all is well with you! I'm emailing you regarding two of our SCORM packages: 
- Managing Unconscious Bias in Performance Reviews
- Managing Unconscious Bias in Hiring
We are failing to upload these SCORMs properly and are getting this error message: Failed - There is a file in each zip which appears to be too long
We believe this might be due to some assets within the SCORMs that have very long names such as GL_LDSP_MUBPRFCRW: languages/PortugueseB/scormcontent/assets/businessman-in-formal-clothes-is-with-black-man-ou-2023-11-27-05-03-29-utc.jpg
Would it be possible to shorten the lengths of the names of these assets (and ensure this doesn't "break" any of the functionality within the course) and reshare the SCORMs?
Please let me know if you have any questions. Thank you!
-- 
Al Morali
he/him
Senior Instructional Designer
Colgate-Palmolive Company
909 River Road, Piscataway, NJ US 08855

Subject:

Some LMS and company security environments can have an impact on the size of certain projects loaded onto an LMS. That doesn't mean anything is wrong with the size of the current package, but something I made their team aware of early on. I've seen some LMS that have a limit on the size of courses. Should they need an adjustment in the course size for them, the videos would need to be re-encoded for a smaller file size. Let's see if they have an issue before quoting a few more hours to re-encode and craft a new wrapper.
 
If they tested MBR and it works, that was the largest file, so perhaps we're all good?
 
Best,
Dustin
 
On Wed, Dec 11, 2024 at 4:27
 
PM Patricia Coleman <
p.coleman@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Hi Dustin,
 
We had our last scheduled call of the year with ColPal.
 
First, of all, they are wondering if it is possible to add a survey link ( they would provide) to the package so that participants give their feedback after each e-learning. Let me know if that is doable and if so, out of the type of files, multi vs single scorm, which one can update the current uploaded files without replacing them ( if that is at all possible). Then, we can talk time needed and your fee separately. 
  
ML Recruiting uploaded, tested and works. CBS is working fast, that’s good!
 
Possible COLPAL MLS reported issue ( not LCW):
It seems that 1 or maybe 2 ML(s) are too big to upload. Al is checking precedents of this issue as they may have a solution.
 
Al shared that they have had bigger files in the past with up to 12  languages. He will advise and ONLY loop back to us if they cannot identify the issue.
 
Dustin, Chuck: Have you encountered this issue before?
 
 
Let me know if you have any questions,
 
Patricia
 
Patricia M Coleman 
(She-Elle-Ella)
Sr Consultant  
LCW

Subject:
 GroupM Zoom Questions
 
External:
 
Hi team,
 
Answers for zoom questions below:
 
Can we customize the Zoom registration confirmation email that goes to participants? Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email can be customized. You can customize the email subject, body of the email, and you can add branding. 
 
Can our Zoom automatically send registrants a calendar invitation? And can we customize the text on it for them?
 
Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email typically includes an option to add the session details to a participant's calendar by clicking an "Add to Calendar" button, allowing them to add the event to their calendar. But THEY have to click the button and add it.  And I can change the email contact to someone besides the primary host, even though it's their account the session is made under. 
 
·
                     
How does the reg link work when there are many session dates/times to choose from? Do we give them a different reg link for each session?  A Zoom meeting can have what they call multiple "occurrences." When you select that registration for the occurrences/sessions is required, you get to choose from three options (see below). 
You can set up the registration page to have multiple dates and times for them to choose from. See the example below. No need for a registration page per session. 
 
Please let me know if you have any questions!
 
Thank you, 
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

Hi Juri and Rebecca,
 
We have a meeting with APAC tonight that I see you (Juri) have accepted. We wanted to give you the heads up on some questions and asks we will be bringing up at this meeting.
Can you confirm again that you will be joining us tonight for the APAC ARCH meeting?
Is LCW able to track and share attendance during these APAC pilot sessions? Can you explain what that tracking looks like as we will need to make sure we have accurate attendance for this session. In the future, we will be able to track.
How will LCW share the course evaluations data for the UYCL and LI sessions? There are survey evaluations at the end of the two presentations.
In a previous email from Rebecca on 2/3 she mentioned that she did not find any 2024 course evaluations as BSC has sent their own. Can you double check if LCW has a survey and/or collected evaluations in the past for the Leading Inclusively sessions and Cultural Immersion sessions that LCW has facilitated for us?
Best,
Evan

Rebecca

External:
 
Hi team,
 
Answers for zoom questions below:
 
Can we customize the Zoom registration confirmation email that goes to participants? Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email can be customized. You can customize the email subject, body of the email, and you can add branding. 
 
Can our Zoom automatically send registrants a calendar invitation? And can we customize the text on it for them?
 
Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email typically includes an option to add the session details to a participant's calendar by clicking an "Add to Calendar" button, allowing them to add the event to their calendar. But THEY have to click the button and add it.  And I can change the email contact to someone besides the primary host, even though it's their account the session is made under. 
 
·
                     
How does the reg link work when there are many session dates/times to choose from? Do we give them a different reg link for each session?  A Zoom meeting can have what they call multiple "occurrences." When you select that registration for the occurrences/sessions is required, you get to choose from three options (see below). 
You can set up the registration page to have multiple dates and times for them to choose from. See the example below. No need for a registration page per session. 
 
Please let me know if you have any questions!
 
Thank you, 
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

Some LMS and company security environments can have an impact on the size of certain projects loaded onto an LMS. That doesn't mean anything is wrong with the size of the current package, but something I made their team aware of early on. I've seen some LMS that have a limit on the size of courses. Should they need an adjustment in the course size for them, the videos would need to be re-encoded for a smaller file size. Let's see if they have an issue before quoting a few more hours to re-encode and craft a new wrapper.
 
If they tested MBR and it works, that was the largest file, so perhaps we're all good?
 
Best,
Dustin

p.coleman@lcwmail.com

Hi Dustin,

First, of all, they are wondering if it is possible to add a survey link ( they would provide) to the package so that participants give their feedback after each e-learning. ML Recruiting uploaded, tested and works. CBS is working fast, that’s good!

Let me know if you have any questions,

How to share your link politely
Before you copy and paste your scheduling link into emails or DMs, make sure your message is well received by wording it thoughtfully.
Share my booking link
 
Here are some examples to try:
“Feel free to share some times that you’re available, or you can also pick from my Calendly if it’s easier.”
“Here’s my availability, but I’m happy to use another method of booking if you’d prefer.”
“Do you have a Calendly or schedule you can share with me? Alternatively, here’s my Calendly if you want to find a time that works.”
Share your link:
https://calendly.com/j-mansour-lcwmail

Subject:
 GroupM Zoom Questions
 
External:
 
Hi team,
 
Answers for zoom questions below:
 
Can we customize the Zoom registration confirmation email that goes to participants? Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email can be customized. You can customize the email subject, body of the email, and you can add branding. 
 
Can our Zoom automatically send registrants a calendar invitation? And can we customize the text on it for them?
 
Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email typically includes an option to add the session details to a participant's calendar by clicking an "Add to Calendar" button, allowing them to add the event to their calendar. But THEY have to click the button and add it.  And I can change the email contact to someone besides the primary host, even though it's their account the session is made under. 
 
·
                     
How does the reg link work when there are many session dates/times to choose from? Do we give them a different reg link for each session?  A Zoom meeting can have what they call multiple "occurrences." When you select that registration for the occurrences/sessions is required, you get to choose from three options (see below). 
You can set up the registration page to have multiple dates and times for them to choose from. See the example below. No need for a registration page per session. 
 
Please let me know if you have any questions!
 
Thank you, 
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

Subject:
 RE: ARCH for LATAM follow up actions
 
Hi Priscila,
 
Thanks for providing the information and follow-up. Regarding your question about splitting the audiences, my recommendation is to separate the groups of native Spanish and Portuguese speakers, provided that you can arrange facilitators for each language. I think this will ensure a more engaging and effective training experience for both groups.
 
I have a couple of questions as well:
1. Is there a specific number of people we should include for the program for this year? 
We are looking to have 250 people take each session this year. For 2025, we have 5 sessions of Understanding Your Cultural Lens (UYCL) and 5 Leading Inclusively (LI) sessions. We have another 200 seats for 2026. 
2. How far apart should we schedule the sessions? 
This really depends on what we decide. I would suggest 1-2 sessions per month starting in May. Ideally, people will sign up for their UYCL and LI sessions at the same time. We can choose to offer more UYCL sessions earlier on and more LI later or we can choose to offer one UYCL and one LI per month and treat the registrations like monthly cohort for the program. 
3. Will there be any local costs associated with the training?
 For 2025 and 2026 this cost is covered by the Global Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion team. The only potential cost I can think of is language translation for the training deck, which would be an additional regional cost. We can talk more about this option if interested at our next meeting. 
 
Looking forward to your response and further details.
 
Best regards,
 
Luis Zúñiga Gamboa,
 Prin. L&D Specialist 
Learning &Development, HR
Tel (506) 4105 7332
luis.zuniga@bsci.com
 Coyol - Alajuela, Costa Rica

Hi Juri and Rebecca,
 
We have a meeting with APAC tonight that I see you (Juri) have accepted. We wanted to give you the heads up on some questions and asks we will be bringing up at this meeting.
Can you confirm again that you will be joining us tonight for the APAC ARCH meeting?
Is LCW able to track and share attendance during these APAC pilot sessions? Can you explain what that tracking looks like as we will need to make sure we have accurate attendance for this session. In the future, we will be able to track.
How will LCW share the course evaluations data for the UYCL and LI sessions? There are survey evaluations at the end of the two presentations.
In a previous email from Rebecca on 2/3 she mentioned that she did not find any 2024 course evaluations as BSC has sent their own. Can you double check if LCW has a survey and/or collected evaluations in the past for the Leading Inclusively sessions and Cultural Immersion sessions that LCW has facilitated for us?
Best,
Evan

Here we have the final “Understanding Your Cultural Lens” materials:
Deck: 
Understanding Your Cultural Lens_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
UYCL_2025_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Please note this one was created for APAC delivery so it has Yuko’s name and bio, plus a session-specific course eval link.  I do have one last question about this deck – I see a mentimeter activity in UYCL, where participants describe what they saw after watching the man-woman video:
 
 
Should our APAC facilitator use this link? I’m not sure if will work for her? I’m also not sure if she’s familiar with mentimeter, though I can ask her (we have a mentimeter account too, though I’m not super well versed on it yet). Normally we have people write down what they saw by using the annotation function or by writing it in the chat. What do you suggest?
 
And here is the final “Leading Inclusively in APAC” materials:
Deck:

Agenda: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Thanks for being such a great team!
Rebecca

Hi, Jas. We haven’t met, I’m a Principal Consultant at LCW. Your name was forwarded to me by Patricia Coleman (friend and colleague, SIETAR USA in common) and Sarah Nodarse. I understand you worked with us last year, to help Sarah culturally adapt a session for one of our clients (Boston Scientific Corp). Sarah is no longer at LCW, and I am now the account managers for BSC. 
 
We completed the content a few months ago, and the client is now ready to schedule a couple of sessions. Not the same session you helped us with (which is called “Leading Inclusively”) but a pre-req 2-hr session called “Understanding Your Cultural Lens”. We’re looking for a Canadian cultural competence SME and facilitator to help us deliver this course, twice. The target audience are people leaders across departments. 
 
We have the content and facilitator notes ready, and we would of course ensure you are prepared and have everything you need to facilitate effectively.  Client’s locations in Canada are Brampton, Mississauga, Ottawa, and Montreal.
 
I’m happy to walk you through the content. It does have some content about the Intercultural Development Continuum/ IDI – are you certified in this assessment? And if not, how familiar are you with this material?
 
The client has just proposed the following dates (t
he Client’s Canada team would select 1 date from round 1 and one date from round 2):
 
Round 1 options:
Tuesday, May 6, 2025 – 10 am – 12 pm ET
Tuesday, May 13, 2025 – 2 pm – 4 pm ET
 
 
Round 2 options:
Tuesday, May 20, 2025 – 2 pm – 4 pm ET
Tuesday, May 27, 2025
 
– 10 am – 12 pm ET
 
 
Here’s the not-so-great news - our budget is quite small at this time due to current strains to our industry and our small firm…. So we can’t pay our usual rates at this time. We cannot afford to pay more than $250 per hour of facilitation, so the total would be $250*2 hours = $500 * 2 sessions = $1k US (including prep).
 
Would this be something you would be available for and interested in?
 
Later in the year we would ask for your partnership in delivering the 3-hour “Leading Inclusively” course I mentioned above. 
 
Looking forward to hearing from you!
Rebecca

External:
 
Hi team,
 
Answers for zoom questions below:
 
Can we customize the Zoom registration confirmation email that goes to participants? Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email can be customized. You can customize the email subject, body of the email, and you can add branding. 
 
Can our Zoom automatically send registrants a calendar invitation? And can we customize the text on it for them?
 
Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email typically includes an option to add the session details to a participant's calendar by clicking an "Add to Calendar" button, allowing them to add the event to their calendar. But THEY have to click the button and add it.  And I can change the email contact to someone besides the primary host, even though it's their account the session is made under. 
 
·
                
How does the reg link work when there are many session dates/times to choose from? Do we give them a different reg link for each session?  A Zoom meeting can have what they call multiple "occurrences." When you select that registration for the occurrences/sessions is required, you get to choose from three options (see below). 
You can set up the registration page to have multiple dates and times for them to choose from. See the example below. No need for a registration page per session. 
 
Please let me know if you have any questions!
 
Thank you, 
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

Subject:
 GroupM Zoom Questions
 
External:
 
Hi team,
 
Answers for zoom questions below:
 
Can we customize the Zoom registration confirmation email that goes to participants? Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email can be customized. You can customize the email subject, body of the email, and you can add branding. 
 
Can our Zoom automatically send registrants a calendar invitation? And can we customize the text on it for them?
 
Yes, the Zoom registration confirmation email typically includes an option to add the session details to a participant's calendar by clicking an "Add to Calendar" button, allowing them to add the event to their calendar. But THEY have to click the button and add it.  And I can change the email contact to someone besides the primary host, even though it's their account the session is made under. 
 
·
                     
How does the reg link work when there are many session dates/times to choose from? Do we give them a different reg link for each session?  A Zoom meeting can have what they call multiple "occurrences." When you select that registration for the occurrences/sessions is required, you get to choose from three options (see below). 
You can set up the registration page to have multiple dates and times for them to choose from. See the example below. No need for a registration page per session. 
 
Please let me know if you have any questions!
 
Thank you, 
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

Hi Yuko!
 
I hope you are well and staying warm, my friends in Kansai are saying it's been particularly cold this year! We almost had snow in Tokyo last week. I have more information regarding sessions below:
 
2-hr “Understanding Your Cultural Lens” on Friday, March 7th at 11am Beijing time (Thu @ 9pm CT)
3-hour “Leading Inclusively” on Friday, March 21st probably at the same time
 
The audience will be comprised of ~50 HR and Talent Management folks from across APAC (I believe Singapore, Malaysia, India, China [Shanghai, Chengdu, Taipei], Japan). The sessions are meant for people leaders, but the HR folks are experiencing it first to help advocate, clarify and support future participants through their HR channels.
 
Our budget is quite small at this time due to current strains to our industry, as I’m sure you’re well aware…. So we can’t pay our usual rates at this time. We can’t afford to pay more than $300 per hour of facilitation, so the total would be $300*2 + $300*3 = $1500 for both sessions including prep. 
 
Let me know what you think.

Le jeu. 19 déc. 2024 à 19:36, Juri Mansour <
j.mansour@lcwmail.com
> a écrit :
Hi Yuko,
I hope you are well! You come highly recommended by my friend/colleague Patricia Coleman. I am a Project Manager with LCW, as you know from working on the UL Solutions Global Inclusion Forum.
We've been booked to deliver a few virtual workshops for Asia Pacific people leaders from one of our global clients, a large medical devices company. One session is a 2-hour foundational intercultural competence session called "Understanding Your Cultural Lens," and the other is a 3-hour session called "Leading Inclusively." We don't have exact dates yet but have been told they will take place in March/April/May and August/September/October of 2025. We're looking for a skilled and experienced intercultural competence SME/facilitator with an APAC cultural background who would be available and interested in facilitating these sessions for us. The client has leaders in Japan, China, South Korea, India, and five countries in Southeast Asia.
The workshops will be delivered in English, but the client has requested multilingual facilitators just in case it's necessary to revert to participants' native language to answer a question. We're also speaking with a native Chinese speaker, for example. The sessions, which will have about 50 participants each (max), will also need to be delivered during reasonable hours in the region (from India to the Philippines).
We’re in the early stages of planning, but we've begun looking for people potentially interested in working with us on this project. Can you possibly give us an idea of your fee for such a project (assuming you facilitate two "UYCL" sessions and two "Leading Inclusively" sessions)? The content is complete, and we would of course ensure you are prepared and have everything you need to facilitate effectively.
Also, is this your most recent bio? If not, would you mind sharing an updated bio with us? What is your experience facilitating such workshops for corporates?
Arigato!
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

I’ll write up a contract and send it to you today. You don’t need to complete anything else, as I know you’ve worked with us before and you have already signed the General Contractor Agreement and W9.
 
We have always prided ourselves in paying our external consultants commensurate with their experience and skills, so this really pains us (though not as much as it pains you, I realize). We’re definitely committed to readjusting our rates as soon as our finances stabilize. Unfortunately, it’s hard to predict when that will be…
 
As soon as I get the signed contract back from you, I’ll send you the workshop materials! (PPT deck, which contains facilitator/speaker notes, and timed agenda). We’ll set up one or more meetings to talk and go over the content, make sure you understand the client context and are comfortable with the material.
 
We’ll also pass along information about the participant group (roles, cultures) as soon as we get that info from the client. 
 
Thank you for your flexibility and we’re very much looking forward to working with you on this project!

I hope you are well and staying warm, my friends in Kansai are saying it's been particularly cold this year! We almost had snow in Tokyo last week. I have more information regarding sessions below:
 
2-hr “Understanding Your Cultural Lens” on Friday, March 7th at 11am Beijing time (Thu @ 9pm CT)
3-hour “Leading Inclusively” on Friday, March 21st probably at the same time
 
The audience will be comprised of ~50 HR and Talent Management folks from across APAC (I believe Singapore, Malaysia, India, China [Shanghai, Chengdu, Taipei], Japan). The sessions are meant for people leaders, but the HR folks are experiencing it first to help advocate, clarify and support future participants through their HR channels.
 
Our budget is quite small at this time due to current strains to our industry, as I’m sure you’re well aware…. So we can’t pay our usual rates at this time. We can’t afford to pay more than $300 per hour of facilitation, so the total would be $300*2 + $300*3 = $1500 for both sessions including prep. 
 
Let me know what you think.
 
 
 
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

Hi Juri,
I hope you had a wonderful Christmas! I apologize for the slight delay in my response, as I’ve been in Paris for the end-of-year celebrations.
Thank you so much for reaching out and for considering me for this exciting opportunity. I would be delighted to support LCW and the client in delivering these workshops. Based on my experience facilitating similar programs—including my previous collaboration with LCW—I am confident in my ability to deliver impactful sessions for their Asia Pacific leaders.
Regarding fees, here is an outline of my expectations for facilitating sessions with prepared material:
Fee for "Understanding Your Cultural Lens" (2 hours):
 $800-$950 per session
Fee for "Leading Inclusively" (3 hours):
 $1000-$1250 per session
Of course, if this fee structure does not align with LCW's budget, I am happy to discuss and explore options to ensure a mutually agreeable arrangement. It’s an honor to be considered for this project, and I’m committed to delivering value to both LCW and the client.
Additionally, I’ve attached my updated bio and resume adapted to the APAC market, for your reference. Please don’t hesitate to let me know if there are further details or preparations required as we move forward.
Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!
Warm regards,

Le jeu. 19 déc. 2024 à 19:36, Juri Mansour <
j.mansour@lcwmail.com
> a écrit :
Hi Yuko,
I hope you are well! You come highly recommended by my friend/colleague Patricia Coleman. I am a Project Manager with LCW, as you know from working on the UL Solutions Global Inclusion Forum.
We've been booked to deliver a few virtual workshops for Asia Pacific people leaders from one of our global clients, a large medical devices company. One session is a 2-hour foundational intercultural competence session called "Understanding Your Cultural Lens," and the other is a 3-hour session called "Leading Inclusively." We don't have exact dates yet but have been told they will take place in March/April/May and August/September/October of 2025. We're looking for a skilled and experienced intercultural competence SME/facilitator with an APAC cultural background who would be available and interested in facilitating these sessions for us. The client has leaders in Japan, China, South Korea, India, and five countries in Southeast Asia.
The workshops will be delivered in English, but the client has requested multilingual facilitators just in case it's necessary to revert to participants' native language to answer a question. We're also speaking with a native Chinese speaker, for example. The sessions, which will have about 50 participants each (max), will also need to be delivered during reasonable hours in the region (from India to the Philippines).
We’re in the early stages of planning, but we've begun looking for people potentially interested in working with us on this project. Can you possibly give us an idea of your fee for such a project (assuming you facilitate two "UYCL" sessions and two "Leading Inclusively" sessions)? The content is complete, and we would of course ensure you are prepared and have everything you need to facilitate effectively.
Also, is this your most recent bio? If not, would you mind sharing an updated bio with us? What is your experience facilitating such workshops for corporates?
Arigato!
Juri Mansour (She/Her)
Consultant Project Associate
LCW

subject: Creatives: Go from production to posted in record time
body:
Fast-forward your video, image, and audio project collaboration with Replay.
 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
Unite your creative team—no travel required
Replay makes collaborating on audio, video, and image projects a breeze—even when reviewers don’t have Dropbox. Centralize your creative reviews, gather feedback faster, and stay aligned the whole way through.
Try Replay
Try it with your team: Add media to Replay
To add audio, video, or image files to Replay:
Sign in
 for free with your existing Dropbox account.
If this is your first time signing in, you’ll see a demo video—click the back arrow in the top left to get to the Workspace.
From the Workspace, click “Add files” and choose where to import your media from. 
That’s it!
Learn how
Review together in real time
Bring your team together with live review. Watch, mark up, and comment on the same video, image, or audio file in Replay—like you’re all in the same room, no matter where collaborators are located.
Find out more

Subject:

Hi Juri and Rebecca,
 
We have a meeting with APAC tonight that I see you (Juri) have accepted. We wanted to give you the heads up on some questions and asks we will be bringing up at this meeting. 
Can you confirm again that you will be joining us tonight for the APAC ARCH meeting?
Is LCW able to track and share attendance during these APAC pilot sessions? Can you explain what that tracking looks like as we will need to make sure we have accurate attendance for this session. In the future, we will be able to track. 
How will LCW share the course evaluations data for the UYCL and LI sessions? There are survey evaluations at the end of the two presentations.
In a previous email from Rebecca on 2/3 she mentioned that she did not find any 2024 course evaluations as BSC has sent their own. Can you double check if LCW has a survey and/or collected evaluations in the past for the Leading Inclusively sessions and Cultural Immersion sessions that LCW has facilitated for us?
Best,
Evan

CAUTION

Hi, team.
 
Here we have the final “Understanding Your Cultural Lens” materials:
Deck: 
Understanding Your Cultural Lens_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
UYCL_2025_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Please note this one was created for APAC delivery so it has Yuko’s name and bio, plus a session-specific course eval link.  I do have one last question about this deck – I see a mentimeter activity in UYCL, where participants describe what they saw after watching the man-woman video:
 
 
Should our APAC facilitator use this link? I’m not sure if will work for her? I’m also not sure if she’s familiar with mentimeter, though I can ask her (we have a mentimeter account too, though I’m not super well versed on it yet). Normally we have people write down what they saw by using the annotation function or by writing it in the chat. What do you suggest? 
 
And here is the final “Leading Inclusively in APAC” materials:
Deck: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively-Solo facilitator_2024_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Thanks for being such a great team!
Rebecca
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
We help develop the mindsets and systems needed to foster resilient, diverse, and equitable teams that will be successful in a cross-cultural world.
Website
 
|
 
Facebook

I live and work in Chapel Hill, NC – on the traditional homelands of the Occaneechi, Shakori, Eno, and Sissipahaw peoples.

From:
 Tarshish, Evan (he/him/his) <evan.tarshish@bsci.com>
Sent:
 Wednesday, March 12, 2025 8:58 AM
To:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>; Bird, Shani (she/her/hers) <Shani.Bird@bsci.com>; Delgado Carranza, Priscila (she/her/hers) <Priscila.DelgadoCarranza@bsci.com>; Juri Mansour <j.mansour@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: {External} Final UYCL and Leading Inclusively: APAC
 
 
Hi Juri and Rebecca,
 
We have a meeting with APAC tonight that I see you (Juri) have accepted. We wanted to give you the heads up on some questions and asks we will be bringing up at this meeting. 
Can you confirm again that you will be joining us tonight for the APAC ARCH meeting?
Is LCW able to track and share attendance during these APAC pilot sessions? Can you explain what that tracking looks like as we will need to make sure we have accurate attendance for this session. In the future, we will be able to track. 
How will LCW share the course evaluations data for the UYCL and LI sessions? There are survey evaluations at the end of the two presentations.
In a previous email from Rebecca on 2/3 she mentioned that she did not find any 2024 course evaluations as BSC has sent their own. Can you double check if LCW has a survey and/or collected evaluations in the past for the Leading Inclusively sessions and Cultural Immersion sessions that LCW has facilitated for us?
Best,
Evan
 
From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, March 5, 2025 3:40 PM
To:
 Tarshish, Evan (he/him/his) <evan.tarshish@bsci.com>; Bird, Shani (she/her/hers) <Shani.Bird@bsci.com>; Delgado Carranza, Priscila (she/her/hers) <Priscila.DelgadoCarranza@bsci.com>
Cc:
 Juri Mansour <j.mansour@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 {External} Final UYCL and Leading Inclusively: APAC
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi, team.
 
Here we have the final “Understanding Your Cultural Lens” materials:
Deck: 
Understanding Your Cultural Lens_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
UYCL_2025_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Please note this one was created for APAC delivery so it has Yuko’s name and bio, plus a session-specific course eval link.  I do have one last question about this deck – I see a mentimeter activity in UYCL, where participants describe what they saw after watching the man-woman video:
 
 
Should our APAC facilitator use this link? I’m not sure if will work for her? I’m also not sure if she’s familiar with mentimeter, though I can ask her (we have a mentimeter account too, though I’m not super well versed on it yet). Normally we have people write down what they saw by using the annotation function or by writing it in the chat. What do you suggest? 
 
And here is the final “Leading Inclusively in APAC” materials:
Deck: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively-Solo facilitator_2024_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Thanks for being such a great team!
Rebecca
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

subject: RE: {External} Final UYCL and Leading Inclusively: APAC
body:
Hi Juri and Rebecca,
 
We have a meeting with APAC tonight that I see you (Juri) have accepted. We wanted to give you the heads up on some questions and asks we will be bringing up at this meeting. 
Can you confirm again that you will be joining us tonight for the APAC ARCH meeting?
Is LCW able to track and share attendance during these APAC pilot sessions? Can you explain what that tracking looks like as we will need to make sure we have accurate attendance for this session. In the future, we will be able to track. 
How will LCW share the course evaluations data for the UYCL and LI sessions? There are survey evaluations at the end of the two presentations.
In a previous email from Rebecca on 2/3 she mentioned that she did not find any 2024 course evaluations as BSC has sent their own. Can you double check if LCW has a survey and/or collected evaluations in the past for the Leading Inclusively sessions and Cultural Immersion sessions that LCW has facilitated for us?
Best,
Evan
 
From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, March 5, 2025 3:40 PM
To:
 Tarshish, Evan (he/him/his) <evan.tarshish@bsci.com>; Bird, Shani (she/her/hers) <Shani.Bird@bsci.com>; Delgado Carranza, Priscila (she/her/hers) <Priscila.DelgadoCarranza@bsci.com>
Cc:
 Juri Mansour <j.mansour@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 {External} Final UYCL and Leading Inclusively: APAC
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi, team.
 
Here we have the final “Understanding Your Cultural Lens” materials:
Deck: 
Understanding Your Cultural Lens_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
UYCL_2025_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Please note this one was created for APAC delivery so it has Yuko’s name and bio, plus a session-specific course eval link.  I do have one last question about this deck – I see a mentimeter activity in UYCL, where participants describe what they saw after watching the man-woman video:
 
 
Should our APAC facilitator use this link? I’m not sure if will work for her? I’m also not sure if she’s familiar with mentimeter, though I can ask her (we have a mentimeter account too, though I’m not super well versed on it yet). Normally we have people write down what they saw by using the annotation function or by writing it in the chat. What do you suggest? 
 
And here is the final “Leading Inclusively in APAC” materials:
Deck: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively-Solo facilitator_2024_FINAL.pptx
Agenda: 
APAC_Leading Inclusively_AGENDA.xlsx
 
Thanks for being such a great team!
Rebecca
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her)

We help develop the mindsets and systems needed to foster resilient, diverse, and equitable teams that will be successful in a cross-cultural world.

PM Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
 
Hi, Jas. We haven’t met, I’m a Principal Consultant at LCW. Your name was forwarded to me by Patricia Coleman (friend and colleague, SIETAR USA in common) and Sarah Nodarse. I understand you worked with us last year, to help Sarah culturally adapt a session for one of our clients (Boston Scientific Corp). Sarah is no longer at LCW, and I am now the account managers for BSC. 
 
We completed the content a few months ago, and the client is now ready to schedule a couple of sessions. Not the same session you helped us with (which is called “Leading Inclusively”) but a pre-req 2-hr session called “Understanding Your Cultural Lens”. We’re looking for a Canadian cultural competence SME and facilitator to help us deliver this course, twice. The target audience are people leaders across departments. 
 
We have the content and facilitator notes ready, and we would of course ensure you are prepared and have everything you need to facilitate effectively.  Client’s locations in Canada are Brampton, Mississauga, Ottawa, and Montreal.
 
I’m happy to walk you through the content. It does have some content about the Intercultural Development Continuum/ IDI – are you certified in this assessment? And if not, how familiar are you with this material?
 
The client has just proposed the following dates (t
he Client’s Canada team would select 1 date from round 1 and one date from round 2):
 
Round 1 options:
Tuesday, May 6, 2025 – 10 am – 12 pm ET
Tuesday, May 13, 2025 – 2 pm – 4 pm ET
 
 
Round 2 options:
Tuesday, May 20, 2025 – 2 pm – 4 pm ET
Tuesday, May 27, 2025
 
– 10 am – 12 pm ET
 
 
Here’s the not-so-great news - our budget is quite small at this time due to current strains to our industry and our small firm…. So we can’t pay our usual rates at this time. We cannot afford to pay more than $250 per hour of facilitation, so the total would be $250*2 hours = $500 * 2 sessions = $1k US (including prep).
 
Would this be something you would be available for and interested in?
 
Later in the year we would ask for your partnership in delivering the 3-hour “Leading Inclusively” course I mentioned above. 
 
Looking forward to hearing from you!
Rebecca

r.parrilla@lcwmail.com

Hi, Jas. We haven’t met, I’m a Principal Consultant at LCW. Your name was forwarded to me by Patricia Coleman (friend and colleague, SIETAR USA in common) and Sarah Nodarse. I understand you worked with us last year, to help Sarah culturally adapt a session for one of our clients (Boston Scientific Corp). Sarah is no longer at LCW, and I am now the account managers for BSC. 
 
We completed the content a few months ago, and the client is now ready to schedule a couple of sessions. Not the same session you helped us with (which is called “Leading Inclusively”) but a pre-req 2-hr session called “Understanding Your Cultural Lens”. We’re looking for a Canadian cultural competence SME and facilitator to help us deliver this course, twice. The target audience are people leaders across departments. 
 
We have the content and facilitator notes ready, and we would of course ensure you are prepared and have everything you need to facilitate effectively.  Client’s locations in Canada are Brampton, Mississauga, Ottawa, and Montreal.
 
I’m happy to walk you through the content. It does have some content about the Intercultural Development Continuum/ IDI – are you certified in this assessment? And if not, how familiar are you with this material?
 
The client has just proposed the following dates (t
he Client’s Canada team would select 1 date from round 1 and one date from round 2):
 
Round 1 options:
Tuesday, May 6, 2025 – 10 am – 12 pm ET
Tuesday, May 13, 2025 – 2 pm – 4 pm ET
 
 
Round 2 options:
Tuesday, May 20, 2025 – 2 pm – 4 pm ET
Tuesday, May 27, 2025
 
– 10 am – 12 pm ET
 
 
Here’s the not-so-great news - our budget is quite small at this time due to current strains to our industry and our small firm…. So we can’t pay our usual rates at this time. We cannot afford to pay more than $250 per hour of facilitation, so the total would be $250*2 hours = $500 * 2 sessions = $1k US (including prep).
 
Would this be something you would be available for and interested in?
 
Later in the year we would ask for your partnership in delivering the 3-hour “Leading Inclusively” course I mentioned above. 
 
Looking forward to hearing from you!
Rebecca
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
